VOL. XX, NO. 3.

AUSEITR
BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 25, 1915.

WASHINGTON COLLEGE CRUSHED

LECTURE SEASON BEGINS SOON

DR. GILDERSLEEVE EIGHTY-FOUR

Black and Blue Overwhelms Chestertown
Team,62 to 6- Line Plays Remarkable Game—Washington's Forward Passes Good.

President Goodnow to Deliver First of
Series for this Year-Many Interesting Subjects to
Be Presented.

Hopkins' "Grand Old Man" Celebrates
Birthday Informally Saturday -Enjoys Good Health, and Works
on New Grammar.

Washington College proved an
easy matter for the Johns Hopkins
eleven Saturday on Homewood
Field, the final score of the game
being 62 to 6. The Black and Blue
line played a wonderful game; the
Chestertown team did not succeed
once in penetrating it for gain,
while the main portion of the
ground gained by Hopkins was
covered through ,holes made by the
husky Hopkins linesmen.
Very little open play was used by
the 'Varsity. Out of three forward
passes which were attempted only
one was completed. This department of the game proved to be the
strong point of the Washington
College team; in the last period
Enright sent the ball repeatedly
into the hands of his ends for short,
but sure, gains. The open play of
the Chestertown team was above the
average, but the powerful Aggressiveness of the Black and Blue line,
coupled with the heavy reinforcement of the backs, made gains
through the line impossible for the
Eastern Shoremen, and smothered
most of their plays before the man
with the ball got as far as his ends.
When Hopkins had the ball, the
game amounted practically to a procession. With Hoffman, Uhler and
Branham carrying the ball, long
gains were made at will through
any part of the line. The tackling
of the Black and Blue team as a
whole was sure and hard.
The scoring resulted as follows:
In the first quarter touchdowns
by
Bowers and Hoffman, Wilkinson
kicking goal. In the second quarter Uhler made two touchdowns.
In the third
period Washington
scored on a forward pass which
Wallace intercepted, running 60
yards to the goal line. Hoffman,
Bowers and Wilkinson each scored
touchdowns in the third quarter.
There was no score in the last
peri6d.
The stars of the game were Martindale, Bowers, Wilkinson, Capt.
Primrose and Barclay for Hopkins,
and Enright and
Young for Washington College.
The line-up,and summary:

The first of the series of fall lectures to be given in McCoy Hall
will take place on November 4,
when Dr. Frank Johnson Goodnow,
president of the University, will address the Municipal Art Society and
the Woman's Civic League on "Municipal Problems."
At a luncheon held last Tuesday
the plans for the Thursday evening
lectures, held under the joint auspices of the societies, were discussed. These have been arranged
for through the University, and Dr.
William Bullock Clark, of the
faculty, who has had charge of the
matter, presided at the meeting after
a few preliminary remarks by Mrs.
Francis King Carey, chairman of
the committee. The lectures will be
devoted to the problems of the city,
and will be delivered by men of
national fame. The completed program of the eight lectures, however, has not yet been announced.
From the present outlook it seems
doubtful whether the lectures to be
given this fall will compare in number with those given last year before Christmas. At that time Dr.
Cunningham gave his notable series
on English Towns; Dr. and Mrs.
Workman told of their work in the
exploration of the Rose Glacier, and
a number of other prominent speakers, such as Dr. Luther Anderson,
of China, gave interesting addresses.
The season of 1916, nevertheless,
will be full of interest to lecturegoers. The Turnbull lectures, instituted in 1889 by Mr. and Mrs.
Lawrence Turnbull in memory of
their son, Percy Graeme Turnbull,
that an annual course of lectures on
poetry might be given by someone
from among "the properly qualified
authors, writers, or professors of
America or Europe," will be 'delivered by Paul Elmer More. Hisspecific subject has not yet been announced, but will be on some phase
of American poetry. It will be remembered that last year Sir Walter
Raleigh, of Oxford, gave the series,
his subject being "Chaucer." Mr.
More was associate professor of
sanskrit at Harvard and at Bryn
Mawr, and later the literary editor
of The hzdePendent. Since 1903 he
has served in the latter capacity on
the staff of the New York Evening
Post, and since 1909 he has been
one of the editors of The Nation.
Mr. More is the author of an admirable translation of the "Promethus Bound" of Xschylus, and
of a life of Benjamin Franklin. He

Last Saturday, quietly and without ceremony, Dr. Basil L. Gildersleeve celebrated his eighty-fourth
birthday.
His eightieth birthday was such
a strenuous one, Dr. Gildersleeve
remarked, that he has been observing the ones since that time as
quietly as possible. He spent the
day working in his library at the
University, and fulfilling several
social engagements.
"It seems strange sometimes to
think that I have lived beyond most
of my old associates," Dr. Gildersleeve said, when interviewed, "but
I shall quietly continue to do as
much work as possible until the
end. I have several books in preparation, and I have come to regard
them almost as grandchildren and
to love them."
Dr. Gildersleeve spoke of the way
in which his friend, Frederic Harrison, the great English essayist and
writer, observed his eightieth birth-S
day—a long walk in the country
and, in the late afternoon, tea with
his friends. It is remarkable that
Frederic Harrison and or. Gildersleeve are almost the same age, both
having been born in October, 1831.
Dr. Gildersleeve was born in
Charleston, N. C. He graduated
at Princeton in 1849 and studied
under Franz in Berlin, under Frederich Ritschl at Bonn and under
Schneidewin at Giittingen, where
he received his doctor's degree in
-1853.
From 1856 to 1876 he was professor of Greek at the University
of Pennsylvania, also holding the
chair of Latin from 1861 to 1866.
In 1876 he became professor of
Greek at Johns Hopkins Univers:ty, founded that year.
In 188o The American Jour.,nal of
Philology, a quarterly published by
the University, was established under his editorial charge. He published a Latin grammar in 1867
and an edition of "Persius" in 1875.
Dr. Gildersleeve's bent, however,
was always more towards Greek
than towards Latin. His special interest in Christian Greek was partly
the cause of his editing "The Apologies of Justin Martyr," in 1877.
From this time on"he published
several syntaxes and edited many
Greek classics. His collected contributions to literary periodicals appeared in 1890 under the title "Essays and Studies,. Educational and
Literary." •
Dr. Gildersleeve gave up teaching at Hopkins last year and now
merely retains his library and office
in McCoy Hall.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
ELEVEN NOW AT CRUCIAL
PERIOD OF DEVELOPMENT
Time at Hand When Black and Blue
Football Team Can Be Made or
Broken -Enthusiastic Support,
in Great Part Lacking, Absolutely Necessary for
Success.
By COACH CHARLES E.:BRICKLEY.

Saturday's game with Washington College showed a great improvement in the fundamental play
of the Hopkins team, but there are
weaknesses which must be remedied before we can hope to defeat
strong teams like Swarthmore, Gettysburg, Haverford, St. John's and
Maryland Agricultural College.
The Washington team proved
very disappointing and showed very
little good football outside their forward passing and punting. The
development of their team 1-ias been
held back by injuries all season.
At intervals the Hopkins offense
played with machine-like precision
and a power that was not to be denied, but after each flash of strength
would come a let-down, during
which the play of the team was very
mediocre. The forward pass was
almost a negligible quantity from
the Hopkins standpoint, due to the
fact that nobody on the squad
seems to know how to catch a pass
in spite of the time spent in practicing this art.
The defense of the team was, on
the whole, very good. Of course,
it did not look so strong against
forward passes, but any team that
makes as many attempts as Washington College did is bound to succeed in some of them. But no
credit should be taken from Enright,
of Washington, who is certainly
clever at throwing the ball. The
work on the receiving end was just
as clever.' Hopkins' stand on its
own goal line was a pleasing affair
to the coaches. Perhaps the most
disappointing feature of the game
was the failure of the team to go
down fast under the kick-off. From
the side lines they seemed almost
to be walking.
So much for that game. The
game with Swarthmore should be
a hard one, and ought to test the
Hopkins team under pressure. It
is one thing to play with the score
many points in your favor and another story to play when the least
break or mistake means the loss of
the game. Whether or not Hopkins is the sort of team that breaks
under pressure will be surely proved
in one of the next three games.
A discouraging feature of last
week's practice was the falling offin the number and faithfulness of
the "scrubs." If the 'Varsity is to
be successful, it must have men to

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 25, 1915.
Insubordination of Freshmen.

19

It seems that in spite of the efforts of the Student Council in the
direction of preventing trouble between the two under-classes, recent
infractions of the newly laid down
freshman regulations on the part
of the members of the Class of
1919 have been the cause of several
tilts between sophomores and freshmen. It has even come to our
notice that one of the officers of
the first-year class was a leader in
the most prominent display of disregard of student law by the freshmen, and, as far as that in itself
is concerned, we can only say that
the student in question has clearly
demonstrated his unfitness to represent his class in the capacity of an
officer, if not to be a student of
Johns Hopkins.
The insubordination of some of
the freshmen has brought up the
problem of enforcing the regulations in the event of their refusal
to obey. If the sophomores are to
take up the matter of disciplining
the offenders, the development of
the system will amount practically
to a reversion to the old methods
of hazing, a thing which in the evident intention of the Student Council is directly in opposition to the
purpose of the new laws. Any
disorganized attempt at enforcing
the rules made by sophomores is
almost certain to result in various
forms of interclass fights of the

kind the regulations are intended to
avoid.
It is clear, then, that if the new
scheme is to be put into effective use,
some satisfactory means of dealing with unruly freshmen must be
devised. If the offenders are to be
made to feel that they are acting
in direct opposition to the, will of
the upper-classmen and that the
upper-classmen have within their
immediate grasp a means of making the culprits suffer without going against the spirit of the regulations, some measure must be introduced immediately to place in
the hands of the Student Council
the power to punish those who act
against the spirit of the University.
THE NEWS-LETTER ventures to suggest that an efficient form of punishment might be found in forbidding any freshman found guilty,
after trial by the Student Council,
to enter into any form of student
activity and in requesting the students in general to ostracize him
socially. An agreement might be
made among the different activities
under whose terms no convicted
freshman could try out for any
team or club or attend any University function, such as the athletic games, cotillons or Musical
Club concerts.
Certainly a decision of some kind
must be made now, if we are to enjoy the benefits of the rules under
peaceful conditions. There is no
real need of unsanctioned strife between the two lower classes; the
interclass feeling can be vented in
prearranged contests and in the
satisfaction of the sophomores in
knowing that the freshmen are being made to know their place and
to remain subordinated during the
period of effect of the regulations.
It may be more or less true that
a fuller satisfaction is gained by
the sophomores in hazing the freshmen, but if we are to stand by the
agreement we have made, such
action must be done away with.
Cases of violation of the rules must
be dealt with by the Student Council in regulation fashion and a definitely prearranged punishment must
be meted out.
Let us therefore give this matter our immediate thought and attention, working toward the establishment of a clearly-defined scheme
of action in dealing with refractory
freshmen, and the ultimate satisfaction of all concerned. If the rules
are meant to remain in force and to
accomplish their purpose, we must
act at once.
Military Training.

The question of national preparedness in the event of war has
occupied the minds of the American
people since the outbreak of the
present conflict in Europe, and many
plans calculated to supply the evident lack of men able to defend our
country have been advanced. Not
least important among these is the
introduction of courses in military
training in colleges and high schools
where no provision is made for that
branch of education.

The institution of such courses
at Johns Hopkins has been discussed and favorable comment has
been made by President Goodnow
and many alumni of prominence.
A committee has been formed to
look into the matter and, although
no definite course of action has as
yet been decided upon, it seems
probable that within a short space
of time students at Johns Hopkins
will have the opportunity to learn
something about how to handle
themselves in military fashion. A
rifle club has already been organ-ized with the end in view of making as many students as possible
familiar with the correct method of
handling the regulation United
States Army rifle.
THE NEWS-LETTER wishes heartily to endorse this action, and to urge
every student to do all he can towards the furtherance of the spirit
among Hopkins men. America is
so situated that methods such as
those employed by some of the foreign powers in the development of
a strong national defense can hardly
be adopted by our government, and
the preparation of the young men
for service in case of need must be
taken up by the men themselves.
It is therefore up to us to do our
share in making patriotism on this
side of the Atlantic really amount
to something, and we can do a great
deal by working with those, alumni
who think enough of their country
to instigate this important movement in its behalf. If courses in
military training are introduced at
Johns Hopkins, it will be the duty
of every student to do all he can to
take advantage of them and to help
Johns Hopkins to do its share of
the work of developing this muchneeded national asset. President
Goodnow was much pleased when
he heard of the favor with which
the plan had met in undergraduate
circles; it is now only right that we
should take up the idea in earnest,
helping all we can to have the
courses instituted and gaining some
real benefit from them when they
are begun.
Saturday's Games—'Varsity's Chances.

Cornell University dedicated a
new stadium—Schoelkopf Field—
on October 9, when the Ithaca team
played the Williams College eleven,
The new field contains, in addition
to the gridiron, a splendid quartermile track with a fine straightaway. Accommodations have been
provided for seating- over nine thousand spectators.
The stadium is located on one
of the highest hills near Ithaca and
commands a wonderful view of the
surrounding country.
Paddling is not the only method
of punishment that is used by
upper-classmen to enforce the wearing of the freshnian cap. At the
Iowa Agricultural College the offending freshman is put through a
process called streshing. A number of upper-classmen seize him by
the feet and hands and throw him
into the air, preventing him from
striking the ground by pulling in
the four directions.
At the Colorado Agricultural College there is a body of water on the
campus called the "Lily Pond." The
first-year men that fail to appear
on the campus with the little green
cap are baptized in the Lily Pond
by the ever-watchful sophomores.
At the University of Washington
the freshman is thrown in the lake;
at Stanford he is held in a bathtub
in encina until the "bubbles come."
Teaching by Sound.

In a certain colored school the
pupils were undergoing a drill in
the meaning and use of words.
"John," said the teacher, "can you
give a sentence containing the words
'defeat' and 'debasement'?"
"De feet slipped on de steps, an'
de boy fell into de basement!" announced John, triumphantly.—Es.

Fair Warning.

The lanky youth who occupied a
seat in a passenger coach persisted
in sticking his head and shoulders
out of the window. The brakeman
was passing through the coach, and
he touched the youth on the back.
"Better keep your head inside the
window," advised the brakeman. .
"I kin look out the winder if I
want to," answered the youth.
"I know you can," warned the
brakeman. "But if you damage any
of the ironwork on the bridges
you'll pay for it."—Ex.

Strangers in Rooting Stand.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Everyone who attended last
Saturday's game was favorably impressed by the change made in the
position of the rooting section, and
by the increased spirit of the Hopkins rooters. I use the term "Hopkins rooters" advisedly, for the one
criticism of the rooting arrangements is that all the men in the
rooting section were not Hopkins
students.
Throughout last year strangers
occasionally came into the section
reserved for rooting, but not in
large enough numbers to call for
comment. Last week, however, so
many crowded into the rooting section that immediate action should be
taken to prevent a repetition of the
performance.
There are two bad effects of
strangers coming into the rooting
section. The first is that the rooting suffers; the second is that other
patrons of the games are discriminated against.
Yell leaders Woodward and
Swartz were seriously hampered in
their efforts last week by the fact
that a large number of men persisted in standing up in the rear of
the section, and would not join in
the rooting. A good proportion of
these men were not Hopkins students, but men from preparatory
schools—so that not having any interest in the University, their refusal to join in the rooting was entirely natural. Other groups of
strangers were scattered through
the stand, and by their contagious
example of silence affected the areas
around them.
Likewise, if some persons are able
to obtain better seats for 50 cents
than those advertised at 75, why
should anyone buy a reserved seat?
Yet, as there are a large number
of persons who do pay the higher
price and yet remain in the sections
set apart for their use, it is manifestly unfair to allow others to obtain better seats at a lower price.
Undoubtedly a good many of the
persons in the rooting section last
Saturday who were not Hopkins
students came there under the misapprehension that this section was
open to all. This very natural mistake could be rectified and all further danger of confusion be eliminated by a request that all students
who go into the rooting section
show their Athletic Association
cards before admittance.
ROOTER.
October 19, 1915.

LOSS OF MEN HARD BLOW
TO ATHLETICS AT YALE

The chalices of Yale to stand
high up in the race for the intercollegiate football championship
were given a severe blow last week
when it was announced .that Pullback Le Gore had been debarred
from further participation in athletics at Yale. Le Gore, Captain
Milburn of the baseball team, and
three other members of the nine
played summer ball and accepted
free board in return. Although
they paid all they owed for board
as soon as they discovered they
were breaking the amateur rules,
still the Yale authorities ruled
them out of athletics entirely.
Several of these men were on the
football squad, and although all of
them were not as important to the
success of the team as Le Gore, yet
with the foOtball team in its present
condition each one's absence will
be severely felt. The New Haven
college, even against these great
odds, is working her very hardest
to fill the gaps and turn out a fast
team.
Juniors to Elect Hullabaloo Board.

The Juniors will hold a class
meeting in the near future to elect
their 1917 Hullabaloo Board. The
committee appointed by the president at the last meeting has not
fully decided upon its selections for
the board, but expects to have the
list ready this week. The members
of the committee are Hall, Baker
and Thompson.
Bagley Heads Student Council.

A brief meeting of the new Student Council, the representatives of
which were elected at the recent
class elections, was held last week
for the purpose of electing a president. Myron E. Bagley, who is a
member of the Senior Class, was
selected for the position.
The other delegates to the Council are Thomas J. Tingley, Edward
P. Hayes and Frederick K. Bell,
from the Senior Class; J. T. Binford and Robert G. Merrick, from
the Junior Class; Stuart W. Egerton, from the Sophomore Class,
and W. Kaspari, from the Freshman Class.
Conflicting Meetings.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—In looking over the notices
on the basement bulletin board
recently, I saw that four separate student meetings were to be
held on the same day and at the
same hour.
Why cannot a system providing
against such conflicts he installed?
The writer suggests that the meeting first posted have precedence
over all other meetings. In that
way all possibility of confusion and
neglect could be eliminated.
JuNius.
October 21, 1915.

McCALLISTER'S

Pea-shell, or shell-pea, originally
an old Welsh pastime, is a game
of royal good fun. The equipment
is simple, as are the players, and
consists merely of two bathtubs and
a barrel of green peas. As many
persons enter the game as are unable to get out of it. Let the janitor or some uninterested person
choose up the sides.
Now, then, the player& stand opposite the barrel of green peas.
Two players start the frolic by
snatching, each, a green pea from
the barrel and shelling it into his
respective tub. The peas are shelled
one by one, the players working in
relays. The side which first fills up
the tub wins the game and is allowed to clear up the pods.
At first the going is slow, but
soon warms up, especially if the hot
water is turned on. Students from
agricultural colleges excel at this
sport. The writer once played in a
game of pea-shell where the opposing side failed to put the stopper in the tub and 487 peas escaped
before a plumber could be called to
diagnose the trouble. Much merriment was provoked. A good plan
is to export the shelled peas to
Belgium for a cannister ; a better
plan is not to export them.—Haryard Lampoon.

Philip Flapdoodle was a genius.
Midyears arrived and with them an
idea. He had upon occasion telegraphed his brother Phidias Flapdoodle in China. The telegram had
arrived seven hours earlier, due to
the change in time. Remarkable!
But if the telegram had continued
westward would it not have returned to Cambridge a whole day
earlier? Certainly. He would enter the exam, seize a paper, rush
out and telegraph it around the
world to himself. He would receive
it the day previous and have a whole
day to study it in.
The day of the exam came. The
telegram had not. What could have
happened? He waited, still it did
not come. Then it dawned upon
him! He had sent the telegram
around the world in the wrong direction! He would not receive it
till tomorrow.
And he didn't.—Harvard Lampoon.

ANNAPOLIS SHORT LINE

The old days of unrestrained
sophomore-freshman rushes were
vividly recalled last Thursday, when
members of the two lower classes
met in a melee in the basement of
the gymnasium.
The origin of the fracas seems to
have been some down upon the
upper lip of a freshman. The
sophomores objected strongly to this
display of manly vigor in one whom
they deemed too young for such a
privilege. Consequently, a crowd
of sophomores gathered together at
the lunch hour, found the offending
freshman and carried him into the
gymnasium. Here he was gently,
but firmly, laid upon the "operating
table" in the Trophy Room, and a
pair of scissors were found and put
into operation.
When this work had been completed, the sophomores surveyed the
gymnasium and found several freshmen standing about in expectant
positions. Deeming this to be a
good opportunity to test the fulfillment of the freshman regulations,
the 1918 men requested the freshmen to step upon the lockers and to
give the various Hopkins yells and
songs. All of the freshmen complied, except one. He, being obstinate, was conveyed to the showerroom.
Just at this moment, however, a
diversion occurred. The Freshman
Class had been having a class meeting, and this had just • been adjourned. Rumors had been afloat,
and the freshmen marched en masse
to the basement.
The results were witnessed by a
crowd of interested upper-classmen.
They were strenuous, but brief.
Much feeling has been stirred up
by this affair, and meetings of the
two lower classes were called for
the day after it occurred to decide
upon future lines of action.

Another disappointing occurrence

There are only four and a half

This is the crucial period of the

team makes or breaks. This is the

when everyone should put his
shoulder to the wheel and do all
in his power to aid the Hopkins
team, to make it develop as it
should into a really great machine.

WASHINGTON COLLEGE CRUSHED

LECTURE SEASON BEGINS SOON

DR. GILDERSLEEVE EIGHTY-FOUR

Black and Blue Overwhelms Chestertown
Team,62 to 6- Line Plays Remarkable Game—Washington's Forward Passes Good.

President Goodnow to Deliver First of
Series for this Year-Many Interesting Subjects to
Be Presented.

Hopkins' "Grand Old Man" Celebrates
Birthday Informally Saturday -Enjoys Good Health, and Works
on New Grammar.

Washington College proved an
easy matter for the Johns Hopkins
eleven Saturday on Homewood
Field, the final score of the game
being 62 to 6. The Black and Blue
line played a wonderful game; the
Chestertown team did not succeed
once in penetrating it for gain,
while the main portion of the
ground gained by Hopkins was
covered through ,holes made by the
husky Hopkins linesmen.
Very little open play was used by
the 'Varsity. Out of three forward
passes which were attempted only
one was completed. This department of the game proved to be the
strong point of the Washington
College team; in the last period
Enright sent the ball repeatedly
into the hands of his ends for short,
but sure, gains. The open play of
the Chestertown team was above the
average, but the powerful Aggressiveness of the Black and Blue line,
coupled with the heavy reinforcement of the backs, made gains
through the line impossible for the
Eastern Shoremen, and smothered
most of their plays before the man
with the ball got as far as his ends.
When Hopkins had the ball, the
game amounted practically to a procession. With Hoffman, Uhler and
Branham carrying the ball, long
gains were made at will through
any part of the line. The tackling
of the Black and Blue team as a
whole was sure and hard.
The scoring resulted as follows:
In the first quarter touchdowns
by
Bowers and Hoffman, Wilkinson
kicking goal. In the second quarter Uhler made two touchdowns.
In the third
period Washington
scored on a forward pass which
Wallace intercepted, running 60
yards to the goal line. Hoffman,
Bowers and Wilkinson each scored
touchdowns in the third quarter.
There was no score in the last
peri6d.
The stars of the game were Martindale, Bowers, Wilkinson, Capt.
Primrose and Barclay for Hopkins,
and Enright and
Young for Washington College.

The first of the series of fall lectures to be given in McCoy Hall
will take place on November 4,
when Dr. Frank Johnson Goodnow,
president of the University, will address the Municipal Art Society and
the Woman's Civic League on "Municipal Problems."
At a luncheon held last Tuesday
the plans for the Thursday evening
lectures, held under the joint auspices of the societies, were discussed. These have been arranged
for through the University, and Dr.
William Bullock Clark, of the
faculty, who has had charge of the
matter, presided at the meeting after
a few preliminary remarks by Mrs.
Francis King Carey, chairman of
the committee. The lectures will be
devoted to the problems of the city,
and will be delivered by men of
national fame. The completed program of the eight lectures, however, has not yet been announced.
From the present outlook it seems
doubtful whether the lectures to be
given this fall will compare in number with those given last year before Christmas. At that time Dr.
Cunningham gave his notable series
on English Towns; Dr. and Mrs.
Workman told of their work in the
exploration of the Rose Glacier, and
a number of other prominent speakers, such as Dr. Luther Anderson,
of China, gave interesting addresses.
The season of 1916, nevertheless,
will be full of interest to lecturegoers. The Turnbull lectures, instituted in 1889 by Mr. and Mrs.
Lawrence Turnbull in memory of
their son, Percy Graeme Turnbull,
that an annual course of lectures on
poetry might be given by someone
from among "the properly qualified
authors, writers, or professors of
America or Europe," will be 'delivered by Paul Elmer More. Hisspecific subject has not yet been announced, but will be on some phase
of American poetry. It will be remembered that last year Sir Walter
Raleigh, of Oxford, gave the series,
his subject being "Chaucer." Mr.
More was associate professor of
sanskrit at Harvard and at Bryn
Mawr, and later the literary editor
of The hzdePendent. Since 1903 he
has served in the latter capacity on
the staff of the New York Evening
Post, and since 1909 he has been
one of the editors of The Nation.
Mr. More is the author of an admirable translation of the "Promethus Bound" of Xschylus, and
of a life of Benjamin Franklin. He

Last Saturday, quietly and without ceremony, Dr. Basil L. Gildersleeve celebrated his eighty-fourth
birthday.
His eightieth birthday was such
a strenuous one, Dr. Gildersleeve
remarked, that he has been observing the ones since that time as
quietly as possible. He spent the
day working in his library at the
University, and fulfilling several
social engagements.
"It seems strange sometimes to
think that I have lived beyond most
of my old associates," Dr. Gildersleeve said, when interviewed, "but
I shall quietly continue to do as
much work as possible until the
end. I have several books in preparation, and I have come to regard
them almost as grandchildren and
to love them."
Dr. Gildersleeve spoke of the way
in which his friend, Frederic Harrison, the great English essayist and
writer, observed his eightieth birth-S
day—a long walk in the country
and, in the late afternoon, tea with
his friends. It is remarkable that
Frederic Harrison and or. Gildersleeve are almost the same age, both
having been born in October, 1831.
Dr. Gildersleeve was born in
Charleston, N. C. He graduated
at Princeton in 1849 and studied
under Franz in Berlin, under Frederich Ritschl at Bonn and under
Schneidewin at Giittingen, where
he received his doctor's degree in
-1853.
From 1856 to 1876 he was professor of Greek at the University
of Pennsylvania, also holding the
chair of Latin from 1861 to 1866.
In 1876 he became professor of
Greek at Johns Hopkins Univers:ty, founded that year.
In 188o The American Jour.,nal of
Philology, a quarterly published by
the University, was established under his editorial charge. He published a Latin grammar in 1867
and an edition of "Persius" in 1875.
Dr. Gildersleeve's bent, however,
was always more towards Greek
than towards Latin. His special interest in Christian Greek was partly
the cause of his editing "The Apologies of Justin Martyr," in 1877.
From this time on"he published
several syntaxes and edited many
Greek classics. His collected contributions to literary periodicals appeared in 1890 under the title "Essays and Studies,. Educational and
Literary." •
Dr. Gildersleeve gave up teaching at Hopkins last year and now
merely retains his library and office
in McCoy Hall.

Saturday's game with Washington College showed a great improvement in the fundamental play
of the Hopkins team, but there are
weaknesses which must be remedied before we can hope to defeat
strong teams like Swarthmore, Gettysburg, Haverford, St. John's and
Maryland Agricultural College.
The Washington team proved
very disappointing and showed very
little good football outside their forward passing and punting. The
development of their team 1-ias been
held back by injuries all season.
At intervals the Hopkins offense
played with machine-like precision
and a power that was not to be denied, but after each flash of strength
would come a let-down, during
which the play of the team was very
mediocre. The forward pass was
almost a negligible quantity from
the Hopkins standpoint, due to the
fact that nobody on the squad
seems to know how to catch a pass
in spite of the time spent in practicing this art.
The defense of the team was, on
the whole, very good. Of course,
it did not look so strong against
forward passes, but any team that
makes as many attempts as Washington College did is bound to succeed in some of them. But no
credit should be taken from Enright,
of Washington, who is certainly
clever at throwing the ball. The
work on the receiving end was just
as clever.' Hopkins' stand on its
own goal line was a pleasing affair
to the coaches. Perhaps the most
disappointing feature of the game
was the failure of the team to go
down fast under the kick-off. From
the side lines they seemed almost
to be walking.
So much for that game. The
game with Swarthmore should be
a hard one, and ought to test the
Hopkins team under pressure. It
is one thing to play with the score
many points in your favor and another story to play when the least
break or mistake means the loss of
the game. Whether or not Hopkins is the sort of team that breaks
under pressure will be surely proved
in one of the next three games.
A discouraging feature of last
week's practice was the falling offin the number and faithfulness of
the "scrubs." If the 'Varsity is to
be successful, it must have men to

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 25, 1915.
Insubordination of Freshmen.

19

It seems that in spite of the efforts of the Student Council in the
direction of preventing trouble between the two under-classes, recent
infractions of the newly laid down
freshman regulations on the part
of the members of the Class of
1919 have been the cause of several
tilts between sophomores and freshmen. It has even come to our
notice that one of the officers of
the first-year class was a leader in
the most prominent display of disregard of student law by the freshmen, and, as far as that in itself
is concerned, we can only say that
the student in question has clearly
demonstrated his unfitness to represent his class in the capacity of an
officer, if not to be a student of
Johns Hopkins.
The insubordination of some of
the freshmen has brought up the
problem of enforcing the regulations in the event of their refusal
to obey. If the sophomores are to
take up the matter of disciplining
the offenders, the development of
the system will amount practically
to a reversion to the old methods
of hazing, a thing which in the evident intention of the Student Council is directly in opposition to the
purpose of the new laws. Any
disorganized attempt at enforcing
the rules made by sophomores is
almost certain to result in various
forms of interclass fights of the

kind the regulations are intended to
avoid.
It is clear, then, that if the new
scheme is to be put into effective use,
some satisfactory means of dealing with unruly freshmen must be
devised. If the offenders are to be
made to feel that they are acting
in direct opposition to the, will of
the upper-classmen and that the
upper-classmen have within their
immediate grasp a means of making the culprits suffer without going against the spirit of the regulations, some measure must be introduced immediately to place in
the hands of the Student Council
the power to punish those who act
against the spirit of the University.
THE NEWS-LETTER ventures to suggest that an efficient form of punishment might be found in forbidding any freshman found guilty,
after trial by the Student Council,
to enter into any form of student
activity and in requesting the students in general to ostracize him
socially. An agreement might be
made among the different activities
under whose terms no convicted
freshman could try out for any
team or club or attend any University function, such as the athletic games, cotillons or Musical
Club concerts.
Certainly a decision of some kind
must be made now, if we are to enjoy the benefits of the rules under
peaceful conditions. There is no
real need of unsanctioned strife between the two lower classes; the
interclass feeling can be vented in
prearranged contests and in the
satisfaction of the sophomores in
knowing that the freshmen are being made to know their place and
to remain subordinated during the
period of effect of the regulations.
It may be more or less true that
a fuller satisfaction is gained by
the sophomores in hazing the freshmen, but if we are to stand by the
agreement we have made, such
action must be done away with.
Cases of violation of the rules must
be dealt with by the Student Council in regulation fashion and a definitely prearranged punishment must
be meted out.
Let us therefore give this matter our immediate thought and attention, working toward the establishment of a clearly-defined scheme
of action in dealing with refractory
freshmen, and the ultimate satisfaction of all concerned. If the rules
are meant to remain in force and to
accomplish their purpose, we must
act at once.
Military Training.

The question of national preparedness in the event of war has
occupied the minds of the American
people since the outbreak of the
present conflict in Europe, and many
plans calculated to supply the evident lack of men able to defend our
country have been advanced. Not
least important among these is the
introduction of courses in military
training in colleges and high schools
where no provision is made for that
branch of education.

The institution of such courses
at Johns Hopkins has been discussed and favorable comment has
been made by President Goodnow
and many alumni of prominence.
A committee has been formed to
look into the matter and, although
no definite course of action has as
yet been decided upon, it seems
probable that within a short space
of time students at Johns Hopkins
will have the opportunity to learn
something about how to handle
themselves in military fashion. A
rifle club has already been organ-ized with the end in view of making as many students as possible
familiar with the correct method of
handling the regulation United
States Army rifle.
THE NEWS-LETTER wishes heartily to endorse this action, and to urge
every student to do all he can towards the furtherance of the spirit
among Hopkins men. America is
so situated that methods such as
those employed by some of the foreign powers in the development of
a strong national defense can hardly
be adopted by our government, and
the preparation of the young men
for service in case of need must be
taken up by the men themselves.
It is therefore up to us to do our
share in making patriotism on this
side of the Atlantic really amount
to something, and we can do a great
deal by working with those, alumni
who think enough of their country
to instigate this important movement in its behalf. If courses in
military training are introduced at
Johns Hopkins, it will be the duty
of every student to do all he can to
take advantage of them and to help
Johns Hopkins to do its share of
the work of developing this muchneeded national asset. President
Goodnow was much pleased when
he heard of the favor with which
the plan had met in undergraduate
circles; it is now only right that we
should take up the idea in earnest,
helping all we can to have the
courses instituted and gaining some
real benefit from them when they
are begun.
Saturday's Games—'Varsity's Chances.

Cornell University dedicated a
new stadium—Schoelkopf Field—
on October 9, when the Ithaca team
played the Williams College eleven,
The new field contains, in addition
to the gridiron, a splendid quartermile track with a fine straightaway. Accommodations have been
provided for seating- over nine thousand spectators.
The stadium is located on one
of the highest hills near Ithaca and
commands a wonderful view of the
surrounding country.
Paddling is not the only method
of punishment that is used by
upper-classmen to enforce the wearing of the freshnian cap. At the
Iowa Agricultural College the offending freshman is put through a
process called streshing. A number of upper-classmen seize him by
the feet and hands and throw him
into the air, preventing him from
striking the ground by pulling in
the four directions.
At the Colorado Agricultural College there is a body of water on the
campus called the "Lily Pond." The
first-year men that fail to appear
on the campus with the little green
cap are baptized in the Lily Pond
by the ever-watchful sophomores.
At the University of Washington
the freshman is thrown in the lake;
at Stanford he is held in a bathtub
in encina until the "bubbles come."
Teaching by Sound.

In a certain colored school the
pupils were undergoing a drill in
the meaning and use of words.
"John," said the teacher, "can you
give a sentence containing the words
'defeat' and 'debasement'?"
"De feet slipped on de steps, an'
de boy fell into de basement!" announced John, triumphantly.—Es.

Fair Warning.

The lanky youth who occupied a
seat in a passenger coach persisted
in sticking his head and shoulders
out of the window. The brakeman
was passing through the coach, and
he touched the youth on the back.
"Better keep your head inside the
window," advised the brakeman. .
"I kin look out the winder if I
want to," answered the youth.
"I know you can," warned the
brakeman. "But if you damage any
of the ironwork on the bridges
you'll pay for it."—Ex.

Strangers in Rooting Stand.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Everyone who attended last
Saturday's game was favorably impressed by the change made in the
position of the rooting section, and
by the increased spirit of the Hopkins rooters. I use the term "Hopkins rooters" advisedly, for the one
criticism of the rooting arrangements is that all the men in the
rooting section were not Hopkins
students.
Throughout last year strangers
occasionally came into the section
reserved for rooting, but not in
large enough numbers to call for
comment. Last week, however, so
many crowded into the rooting section that immediate action should be
taken to prevent a repetition of the
performance.
There are two bad effects of
strangers coming into the rooting
section. The first is that the rooting suffers; the second is that other
patrons of the games are discriminated against.
Yell leaders Woodward and
Swartz were seriously hampered in
their efforts last week by the fact
that a large number of men persisted in standing up in the rear of
the section, and would not join in
the rooting. A good proportion of
these men were not Hopkins students, but men from preparatory
schools—so that not having any interest in the University, their refusal to join in the rooting was entirely natural. Other groups of
strangers were scattered through
the stand, and by their contagious
example of silence affected the areas
around them.
Likewise, if some persons are able
to obtain better seats for 50 cents
than those advertised at 75, why
should anyone buy a reserved seat?
Yet, as there are a large number
of persons who do pay the higher
price and yet remain in the sections
set apart for their use, it is manifestly unfair to allow others to obtain better seats at a lower price.
Undoubtedly a good many of the
persons in the rooting section last
Saturday who were not Hopkins
students came there under the misapprehension that this section was
open to all. This very natural mistake could be rectified and all further danger of confusion be eliminated by a request that all students
who go into the rooting section
show their Athletic Association
cards before admittance.
ROOTER.
October 19, 1915.

LOSS OF MEN HARD BLOW
TO ATHLETICS AT YALE

The chalices of Yale to stand
high up in the race for the intercollegiate football championship
were given a severe blow last week
when it was announced .that Pullback Le Gore had been debarred
from further participation in athletics at Yale. Le Gore, Captain
Milburn of the baseball team, and
three other members of the nine
played summer ball and accepted
free board in return. Although
they paid all they owed for board
as soon as they discovered they
were breaking the amateur rules,
still the Yale authorities ruled
them out of athletics entirely.
Several of these men were on the
football squad, and although all of
them were not as important to the
success of the team as Le Gore, yet
with the foOtball team in its present
condition each one's absence will
be severely felt. The New Haven
college, even against these great
odds, is working her very hardest
to fill the gaps and turn out a fast
team.
Juniors to Elect Hullabaloo Board.

The Juniors will hold a class
meeting in the near future to elect
their 1917 Hullabaloo Board. The
committee appointed by the president at the last meeting has not
fully decided upon its selections for
the board, but expects to have the
list ready this week. The members
of the committee are Hall, Baker
and Thompson.
Bagley Heads Student Council.

A brief meeting of the new Student Council, the representatives of
which were elected at the recent
class elections, was held last week
for the purpose of electing a president. Myron E. Bagley, who is a
member of the Senior Class, was
selected for the position.
The other delegates to the Council are Thomas J. Tingley, Edward
P. Hayes and Frederick K. Bell,
from the Senior Class; J. T. Binford and Robert G. Merrick, from
the Junior Class; Stuart W. Egerton, from the Sophomore Class,
and W. Kaspari, from the Freshman Class.
Conflicting Meetings.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—In looking over the notices
on the basement bulletin board
recently, I saw that four separate student meetings were to be
held on the same day and at the
same hour.
Why cannot a system providing
against such conflicts he installed?
The writer suggests that the meeting first posted have precedence
over all other meetings. In that
way all possibility of confusion and
neglect could be eliminated.
JuNius.
October 21, 1915.

McCALLISTER'S

Pea-shell, or shell-pea, originally
an old Welsh pastime, is a game
of royal good fun. The equipment
is simple, as are the players, and
consists merely of two bathtubs and
a barrel of green peas. As many
persons enter the game as are unable to get out of it. Let the janitor or some uninterested person
choose up the sides.
Now, then, the player& stand opposite the barrel of green peas.
Two players start the frolic by
snatching, each, a green pea from
the barrel and shelling it into his
respective tub. The peas are shelled
one by one, the players working in
relays. The side which first fills up
the tub wins the game and is allowed to clear up the pods.
At first the going is slow, but
soon warms up, especially if the hot
water is turned on. Students from
agricultural colleges excel at this
sport. The writer once played in a
game of pea-shell where the opposing side failed to put the stopper in the tub and 487 peas escaped
before a plumber could be called to
diagnose the trouble. Much merriment was provoked. A good plan
is to export the shelled peas to
Belgium for a cannister ; a better
plan is not to export them.—Haryard Lampoon.

Morton K. Rothschild, '18

Philip Flapdoodle was a genius.
Midyears arrived and with them an
idea. He had upon occasion telegraphed his brother Phidias Flapdoodle in China. The telegram had
arrived seven hours earlier, due to
the change in time. Remarkable!
But if the telegram had continued
westward would it not have returned to Cambridge a whole day
earlier? Certainly. He would enter the exam, seize a paper, rush
out and telegraph it around the
world to himself. He would receive
it the day previous and have a whole
day to study it in.
The day of the exam came. The
telegram had not. What could have
happened? He waited, still it did
not come. Then it dawned upon
him! He had sent the telegram
around the world in the wrong direction! He would not receive it
till tomorrow.
And he didn't.—Harvard Lampoon.

ANNAPOLIS SHORT LINE

The old days of unrestrained
sophomore-freshman rushes were
vividly recalled last Thursday, when
members of the two lower classes
met in a melee in the basement of
the gymnasium.
The origin of the fracas seems to
have been some down upon the
upper lip of a freshman. The
sophomores objected strongly to this
display of manly vigor in one whom
they deemed too young for such a
privilege. Consequently, a crowd
of sophomores gathered together at
the lunch hour, found the offending
freshman and carried him into the
gymnasium. Here he was gently,
but firmly, laid upon the "operating
table" in the Trophy Room, and a
pair of scissors were found and put
into operation.
When this work had been completed, the sophomores surveyed the
gymnasium and found several freshmen standing about in expectant
positions. Deeming this to be a
good opportunity to test the fulfillment of the freshman regulations,
the 1918 men requested the freshmen to step upon the lockers and to
give the various Hopkins yells and
songs. All of the freshmen complied, except one. He, being obstinate, was conveyed to the showerroom.
Just at this moment, however, a
diversion occurred. The Freshman
Class had been having a class meeting, and this had just • been adjourned. Rumors had been afloat,
and the freshmen marched en masse
to the basement.
The results were witnessed by a
crowd of interested upper-classmen.
They were strenuous, but brief.
Much feeling has been stirred up
by this affair, and meetings of the
two lower classes were called for
the day after it occurred to decide
upon future lines of action.

Another disappointing occurrence
is the lateness of some of the undergraduates in reporting for practice.
They seem to be held longer in the
laboratories than when college first
started, and it is getting so that
there is little daylight practice.
There are only four and a half
weeks left now and the men should
make every effort to get out early,
so that we can have daylight practice. It is very essential to keep
up to standard in the scholastic
work, but the men must think more
about football if they expect to be
successful in the big games to come.
This is the crucial period of the
season, the time in which a football
team makes or breaks. This is the
period when help is needed most,
when everyone should put his
shoulder to the wheel and do all
in his power to aid the Hopkins
team, to make it develop as it
should into a really great machine.
